.  It is claimed to be the oldest town in England.
Louth is a fairly small town, and is largely walk-able, especially all the main points of interest around the Church area.
) run the local bus service, although it can be rather unreliable at times. A 'Nipper' ticket is available to travel around Louth-ask the bus driver about this.

value: The tallest parish church spire in the UK and also Lincolnshire's top tourist church.
a well-loved area of green space in the town, with an ice cream shop, a lake great for paddling and lots of ducks to feed.
nearer the middle of town than Hubbard's Hills, Westgate Fields is a nice location for a picnic or just to see the giant Wooden Leaves there.
consisting of the Wooden Leaves, three Meridian Line sculptures and a rather disappointing 'Wind Directional Pointer', following the Art Trail is a good way to explore the town.
runs through the town. A plaque outside Moby Dick's Fish and Chip Shop commemorates where East and Western Hemispheres meet.
- a rather tiring journey to the top, but on a nice day there are lovely views to be had.
- fun for everyone, especially if followed by a picnic or an ice cream.

Louth's centre isn't large, but has some charming shops on offer. Most of the larger chains (e.g. WHSmiths, HMV, M&S) have stayed out of Louth, and the shops are still mostly local, independently run outfits.

value: is a bookseller's, stationer's and newsagent. It also sells a variety of cards and gifts.
content=Is a sports shop, selling sporting clothing and equipment. The shop sign also, rather confusingly, claims it sells 'Pop accessories' as well

proudly states it has been open 'Under 9 Reigns' on a sign by the door, and it is respected as such. A large department store, it is renowned for its homewares, and is where many people in the area buy their tablecloths, generally 'for best' (its history means it can charge a little extra). Sells everything else expected in an English department store, with a rather more refined style than, say, Binns or Debenhams.
is four shops - the original, Dragonfly Gifts, Dragonfly 2 and Dragonfly Kitchen. All good for a special gift or home accessory - a great range of unusual items.
sells original art and prints as well as offering an excellent framing service.  Gift items are also available.  Don't forget to take a dog treat for the boys!

content=Royston’s Deli is Louth’s new fine food shop. We’re right in the middle of Eastgate, opposite Burnt Ash Lane, between Venus and Dragonfly Cards.

We cook and bake everyday in our kitchen at the back of the shop to produce a great range of ready meals, pastries and breads and also sell fine delicatessen foods from around Europe.

Royston's Deli use only the best ingredients and are proud to support local producers. Our meat is supplied by local butchers Meridian Meats and our baking contains only free-range eggs, organic flour and rich Longley Farm butter. Seasonal crops come from Tithe Farm in North Somercotes.
Roxy & Chris
is a legendary (in the area) chip shop, and well worth a visit. Fish and Chips to eat in or take away
is a pub on Westagte serving a variety of traditional ales and delicious (mostly locally produced) pub food

is a fine tea shop on Upgate. Being served afternoon tea by waitresses in Victorian dress is an experiece perfectly suited to the charming surroundings of Louth. Try a Fat Rascal (brilliant scone-type cake) or a more traditional scone with cream and jam for a delightfully English tea.

content=Louth Farmers' Market is held on the 2nd Friday and 4th Wednesday every month in Market Place, Louth. Lots of fresh local food including organic vegetables, free range pork, local cheese and lots more.

Locals will tell you Louth has over fifty pubs - pretty impressive considering its fairly small size. Although fifty might not be altogether accurate, it's not far off, so finding a drinking hole to suit won't be much of a challenge.

value: content=Fully equipped and re-furbished Georgian cottage, self-catering, sleeps 4. Parking, garden and patio. Close to close to Westgate Fields and Hubbards Hills, church and pubs and restaurants.

content=Welcoming 19c farmhouse B&B situated in open farmland on the Lincolnshire coast near the market towns of Louth & Alford and seal colony at Donna Nook. Full English/vegetarian breakfast using local organic produce, home made preserves and eggs from the garden. Ideal for cycling, walking, fishing & photography.
